_prev_prog_3.Description:
Rich Products Corporation - Hilliard Facility's ammonia refrigeration system contains equipment to minimize the potential of an ammonia release.  The Facility has in place the following controls for the ammonia refrigeration system:  preventative maintenance procedures, automatic alarm systems, ammonia detectors and ventilation, process safety information tracking logs, automatic system shutdown capabilities, periodic leak and pressure testing, periodic visual inspections, control valves, refrigeration hand service valves for manual operation, solenoid valves, pressure relief valves, computer generated work orders for maintenance and hot work permits.  The ammonia refrigeration system is run through a refrigeration control system (RCS).  The RCS is programmed to automatically safely shut down equipment and/or the entire process if specified parameters are exceeded, i.e., system alarms occur.  The RCS is used for system monitoring, data trending/logging, and operator set point entry.  Additionally, equipment such as compressors can be operated utilizing programmable logic controllers (PLCs) located on the equipment.  System monitoring is provided through a variety of displays that show equipment status, temperature and pressure readings, current operating settings and various other parameters.  The displays provide the operator with continuous and up to date status of the ammonia refrigeration system.  Of note, set points can only be changed by authorized Associates (i.e., it requires a password to change equipment set points).



The Facility's administrative procedures are as follows:  periodic training for Associates, compliance audits, pre-startup safety checks, process hazard analysis to address what-if scenarios and the measures taken to mitigate a release, screening of all contractors performing work on the ammonia refrigeration system per OSHA and USEPA regulations, and management of change procedures.



Compressors have the following safeguards:  pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping, high and low temperature alarms and shutdown, high and low pressure alarms and shutdown, high and low level oil alarms and shutdown, high and low oil temperature alarms and shutdown, high and low oil pressure alarms and shutdown, thermosyphon oil cooling, discharge stop/check valve, suction valve (i.e., combination stop/check/strainer valve), electronic overload protection with alarm and shutdown, and pressure relief valves.



The intercooler has the following safeguards:  dual pressure relief valves, high and low level alarms and shutdown, continuous level controller, and liquid level sight glasses.



Low pressure recirculator for cold storage has the following safeguards:  high and low level alarms and shutdown, continuous level controller, and two pumps with constant flow regulator, minimum flow orifice and differential pressure switch.



Low pressure recirculator for spiral freezers has the following safeguards:  high and low level alarms and shutdown, continuous level controller, and two pumps with constant flow regulator, minimum flow orifice and differential pressure switch.



Evaporative condenser has the following safeguards:  dual pressure relief valves for each coil circuit, liquid level indicator, water pump startup and shutdown, and high pressure over ride.



High pressure receiver has the following safeguards:  dual pressure relief valves, level column with level indicator and level sight glasses, and high and low level alarms and shutdown.



Evaporators have the following safeguards:  high and low level alarms and shutdown, temperature controls, liquid level gauge, pressure relief valves, high and low pressure alarms and shutdown, emergency stop switch, and pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping.



The purger has the following safeguards:  pressure relief valve, check valves, shutoff valves, metering valves, water bubbler, and liquid level control valves.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
a commercial/light industrial area. The Site occupies an approximately 132,000 square-foot structure that is located on 11.3 acres of land. The Site was originally built in 1980 and has been owned by RPC since 1985. The Site normally operates 6 days per week, 24 hours per day.



The Site manufactures doughnuts, which are frozen for shipment. The Site's North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 31141 (Frozen Food Manufacturing)



As part of the refrigeration system to freeze the doughnuts for shipment, the Site handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical, as defined in the USEPA's CAPP and OSHA's PSM standard, in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold for anhydrous ammonia in a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. The Site is registered to Program Level 3 under the CAPP program.



The anhydrous ammonia is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system. The Site's engine room houses the majority of the refrigeration machinery.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION



While there are few long-term environmental consequences to ammonia use, it can present health hazards if handled improperly. RPC has developed a comprehensive safety program in compliance with OSHA and EPA requirements to ensure the responsible management of the ammonia onsite (the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program, respectively). All refrigeration Associates receive operator training, safe work practices training and training on the standard operating procedures (SOPs). Safety meetings are conducted to further protect Associates and the community as a whole.



The Site's prevention program is designed to inform all Associates of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates and the community in the event of a release or spill.



The Site endeavors to eliminate accide

nts and health hazards to Associates, customers, and the community by having procedures in place to provide Associates educational training, safe working conditions, and the means to increase awareness of potential dangers both on and off the job. RPC's objective is to prevent unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could potentially expose Associates and others to serious hazards. An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire system. Workplace and process safety are major concerns to management and Associates alike. The prevention and mitigation of unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could expose Associates and the community to serious hazards is of primary concern.



The Site has incorporated many safety features in the design of the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Site's ammonia system is continuously monitored by automated control systems that shutdown pump and the components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the system is equipped with pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels and most, if not all, additional locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped.



RPC considers the health and safety of each Associate as its most important responsibility. It is our policy to provide a healthy and safe work environment. This facility follows operating practices that safeguard all associates and result in safe working conditions while maintaining efficient operations.



Safety is the responsibility of all Associates. Each associate is expected to comply with the requirements of RPC's Standards for Safety Performance. Management is responsible for the implementation, communication, documentation, and necessary trainin

g. The Associate is responsible for implementation, communication, and practices of the program. Management is committed to maintain a high level of interest in health and safety throughout this facility. This commitment extends to the associates and their involvement in preventing accidents.



RPC has established its Health and Safety Program to insure that:



-- Associates work in a healthy and safe environment.

-- Associates are trained on safe work practices.

-- Associates practice safe work habits.

-- Management and associates are both involved in the program.

-- There is constant communication between all Associates on safety issues.

-- Compliance with all regulatory agencies is maintained.



Major safety features at the Site include:



-- Installation of Ammonia leak detectors in processing areas and the engine room

-- Remote emergency shutdown switches for the refrigeration system

-- Fire sprinklers throughout the Site

-- Component specific safety shutdowns of the refrigeration system

-- Water-filled diffusion tank to treat accidental release of ammonia through pressure relief valves, and

-- A proprietary Refrigeration Energy Management System (REMS) computer monitoring system.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Site has reported one accidental release over the last five years. While a release was reported as having been discovered on October 18, 2014, further additional investigations determined that a reportable release had not occurred.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Site is equipped with an emergency warning system. Alarms are placed throughout the Site to alarm personnel of an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia or other emergencies that may be encountered. RPC has developed specific procedures to be followed in the event of release. These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so. RPC maintains a w

ritten emergency response plan; however, Site Associates do not currently respond to releases.



As applicable to their duties, Site personnel have received emergency response training as outlined in OSHA's HAZWOPER regulation (29 CFR 1910.120) and other various rules and regulations.



The Norwich Township Fire Department has visited the facility to review the process operations, safety systems and discuss emergency response coordination.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Site recognizes that the implementation of this program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operation at the Site. As such, the prevention program will evolve as RPC continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for the employees and the surrounding community.
